Adapting novels into screenplays is tough: not only does the writer have to pack 400+ pages of backstory, characterization and plot into 100-120 pages of script, but the director is forced to make important choices about where within those pages to point his or her camera. They have to decide what the story is actually about and discriminatingly pluck snippets from the source material to tell it effectively, all while staying true to the author's intent. Luckily for David Fincher and his latest film, Gone Girl, he had Gillian Flynn-the author of the New York Times bestseller of the same name-manning the typewriter. While many will still prefer Flynn's original hardcover to its adaptation (myself included), the Fincher/Flynn tandem spawned a darkly intoxicating film riddled with its fair share of surprises and hilarity, even for those familiar with the story. It's safe to say that if you're planning on seeing 10 movies this year, Gone Girl should be near the top of the list.

The film is about Nick and Amy Dunne, a married New York couple in their mid-thirties who lose their print magazine jobs at the height of the recent recession and are forced to move back to Nick's hometown of North Carthage, Missouri after his mother is diagnosed with breast cancer. Through a series of rosy flashbacks, we catch glimpses of what used to be Nick and Amy's life together in New York: the night they met at a party in Brooklyn, the night Nick proposed at the release party for Amy's parents' most recent childrens book (Amazing Amy and the Big Day-based on their daughter), and the first few years of their blissful marriage. Subtract two jobs and one Manhattan loft, add a substantial loan to Amy's parents from her trust fund and multiply it all by Amy's reluctance to leave the East coast and shack up in a McMansion along the Mississippi River, and it becomes quite clear that the Dunne union has seen better days. Then on their fifth wedding anniversary Amy disappears. The local police scour Nick's house where there are clear signs of a struggle, as well as a letter from Amy: the first clue for the treasure hunt she plans for Nick every year on their anniversary. Gradually, the national media spotlight descends on the small Missouri town and the public turns on Nick when he's suspected for having something to do with his wife's disappearance. As the police investigation develops and the noose continues to tighten around Nick, everyone is left wondering one question: where is Amy Dunne?

However, the question Fincher would rather the audience ask themselves is "Who is Amy Dunne?" To be sure, there is a reason Flynn's novel has sold over 8.5 million copies. It's a thrilling murder mystery that tantalizes us with many of the familiar concepts we've come to expect from both Hollywood and the serial dramas of the small screen, which seem to be more and more concerned about killing than the people doing the killing or trying to stop it (there is even a show called The Killing that ironically, as Grantland's Andy Greenwald laments, just won't die). But Gone Girl avoids the missteps of its peers and provides the audience with considerably more existential questions than what happened to its title character. Fincher, working off of Flynn's themes, crafts his film around the most salient elements of the story that leaves the audience feeling at once shocked by its absurdity and terrified by its implications. At its core, Gone Girl is about serious relationships and the importunate questions that almost always hover above them. Who Amy and Nick are-as individuals and as a couple-prior to the former's disappearance is just as important to Fincher as what happens to Amy (Rosamund Pike) and Nick (Ben Affleck) in the film.

Affleck turns in his finest performance to date as the people-pleasing, unintentionally smug Nick Dunne, opting for downplayed, restrained acting choices much like Christian Bale's subtly scintillating role in last year's American Hustle. Surely a number of other actors could have shined in Gone Girl, but Affleck's dopey charm and topsy-turvy career arc truly resonate with the character.  

While staying true to the general ethos of the novel is admirable, actually augmenting the material in some respects is downright impressive, and not many directors can do it. One of Fincher's greatest gifts is his mastery of light and shadow, so much so that there is something definitively and obviously congruent about all of his work, and specific minutia stand out: the perpetually-stormy, decaying city streets of Seven; the organic, filthiness of Tyler Durden's house in Fight Club; the moody, gloomy halls of Harvard in The Social Network. In Gone Girl, it happens to be from a scene in the trailer where Nick Dunne is standing in the gazebo with the spotlight all over him at a vigil for Amy, explaining to the hundreds of skeptical mourners and reporters that he's innocent. It's a scene that recapitulates Flynn's prose regarding the proliferation of mass media celebrity culture and the gotcha journalism that promotes the sexiest story over the legitimate one. And while chastising the news media is nothing new in film (e.g. Natural Born Killers (1994), Network (1976), and the upcoming Nightcrawler it would appear to a certain extent), there is something simultaneously intimate and surreal about watching Nick and Amy's story unfold, as if we're watching a reality TV show about people we know personally.  

There are at least another dozen scenes that gracefully sew the story together, which is no small task given the manner in which Flynn wrote the book, vacillating between Nick's account of the investigation and Amy's old diary entries, which serve as a flashback mechanism. One scene as reimagined by Fincher evoked literal gasps from the entire theater, while Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross' haunting soundtrack had people squirming in their seats. It's why we pay to go to the movies.

With a month to go until the awards season gets into full swing, Gone Girl becomes the clear front runner in filmgoers' minds as submission for nominations draws near. The impeccably-witty script, good performances by the cast and twist-after-twist-after-twist plotline makes it a serious contender for nominations in the picture, acting, and writing categories. 

The plotline is simple. The disappearance of Elliot-Dune (Rosamund Pike) on the fifth wedding anniversary to husband Nick Dunne (Ben Affleck) creates a media frenzy. The abrupt disappearance or abduction of Amy with no trace becomes national headlines as she is the basis for the famed fictional "Amazing Amy" children's book series. Suspicions soon follow that Affleck's character may have had something to do with the disappearance of Amy as a series of unusual coincidences follow as police begin their investigations. It is later revealed to the audience that Amy has faked her death and set up clues to frame her husband.

What I found compelling about this picture is that it's a genius hustle attempt to get back at your cheating, controlling man. However, this isn't simply a man-hating film. True, Affleck's character has cheated on his wife with a much younger model (a student in fact) as a result of his wife's descending into a mental breakdown and social reclusiveness. This is no way an excuse, but sets the tone for how they're relationship will fan out throughout the film and why it has become so fractured. 
The overarching theme of the picture is pursuing control or the lack of it. Amy's story has been written for her her whole life. She is synonymous with the "goody-goody, wholesome" image her parents created from her as the "ideal little girl" everyone wants in the Amazing Amy stories. When Amy feels entombed by the pretend character based on her life, she ensues in wanting to take "Amazing Amy" into a new direction and tell her own story. Her own destiny. Her way. 

Although clearly going about it the wrong way, Amy finally closes off the final chapter of the series. She is no longer perfect. She and her family have been through an awful experience and she is no longer "Amazing Amy".

You begin to follow the protagonist on her dark journey to self-proclamation. Albeit, the plotline is highly unrealistic, but it's also meant to be a thriller! And more importantly, it's a movie! It does what a thriller is supposed to do: enthral the audience to keep watching, and honestly, you can't stop watching. Director David Fincher's direction of the film leads us to a series of plot twists, confusion, and disbelief. But more importantly, we are lead to almost sympathise with Amy. She is damaged, she is hurt, she is a little crazy but should she be forgiven? By the end of the film, the world seems to have.

Rosamund Pike's incredible versatility is on true display as we are introduce the "cool, collected" Amy: a successful, strong-minded, independent businesswomen. But when the dawns of reality set knocking on her suburban door, she descends into a mental state of completely anarchy and irrationality. It's almost like Pike is essentially playing two entirely different characters in the film who are parallels apart in terms of mind-set, and her transition from one frame of mind to another is almost missable as she gradually transforms the poised businesswoman we see in New York to a frantic housewife pulling on the nation's heartstrings in the midst her disappearance. 

There isn't a bad performance in this picture generally. The star of the picture is Affleck, but the stand out performance of the picture is Pike. The ability to go from stable, serene, frantic, crazy, delusional and pitiful in the space of two hours is very impressive and more importantly, it's genuinely believable. However, I did feel the performance of Neil Patrick Harris as Amy's ex-lover who eventually saves her from being left penniless whilst on the run, added no value to the picture. He was not able to display the type of dominance or sense of control Affleck and Pike displayed so clearly throughout. Stick to the musicals and comedies, Neil! And dare I say it, I thought Tyler Perry's performance was almost a step back for improving the position of ethnic minorities in the film industry. It's almost as if they've hired a black actor to just provide a few comedic laughs in what is a dark, mysterious thriller. I'm not really sure where I stand on his performance, but I'll leave it at that. 

However, there is a disappointment to the film: the ending is bad. In fact, it's annoying. A general consensus amongst those I spoke to after the viewing. Both parties involved how clearly wronged each other, but Amy has deceived to the extent she has completely manipulated the mind of not only her husband, family and the media, but the theatre audience as a whole. Although we begin to sympathise with Amy's situation as the bored housewife, trapped and treated badly by her husband. Our shift in sympathy moves towards Affleck's character. He is trapped for the rest of his life by this manipulative woman and ultimately learns a sad lesson due to the consequences of his infidelity.

Very well done. I read the book, so I knew what was going to happen, but this movie was so well done that I wish I went in cold. "Gone Girl" is an intense psychological thriller with a pretty sarcastic and, I would say, cynical edge. At the very least, it's a great popcorn nailbiter and one loves seeing the devious villain's (who is it?!) scheme come to fruition. At its apex, dissects the notion of marriage and its relationship to social pressures. Couples are pushed to always display a happy face, and this is especially true in the hypersocial Facebook world we live in now, which actually plays quite a big part in the movie. What is love in a world where a couple doesn't just have a relationship with each other, but with everyone? In terms of its cinematic adaptation, I absolutely loved the use of color in the movie. Notice the use of blue and its association between Amy and control. Blue was present in love scenes, past scenes, and showed up constantly in the scenes where Amy's influence was playing an explicit or implicit role. I absolutely loved this visual contrast in the movie. Blue was used so g complexly - representing love and security, but also control and delusion. Maybe that's what love is? A mixture of control and delusion? How dark! In any case, "Gone Girl" was absolutely a delight to watch.

Just watched Gone Girl, so let's hear the reviews. Starring two major underrated stars, Rosamund Pike and Ben Affleck (well not so much) and a strong supporting cast including Kim Dickens, Tyler Perry (just wait) and Neil Patrick Harris among others, the film has been both a commercial and critical success.
The film tells the story of how Nick Dunne (Affleck) got stuck in a messy situation on the search for his wife, Amy Dunne (Pike). Through a series of flashbacks and a string of events in the present day, the film slowly opens up about Nick and Amy's troubled relationship, that included Nick cheating on Amy, got fired, beaten down by the media and got suspected as the murderer. Now, this hasn't even got to the 1 hour mark, and that's just Nick's part of the story.
Halfway through the film, the film made one of the most unexpected twists of the year, turning the narration into the hands of Amy. Turns out, Amy didn't get kidnapped or killed. She was alive and well (not necessarily that well). Amy, growing distressed of Nick's lazy lifestyle and unsatisfied of their misfired marriage, faked her own death in a carefully thought out plan which included: befriending the neighborhood's moron, orchestrating a fake crime scene, fake pregnancy, a game of Anniversary Treasure Hunt and a bloody disgusting pool of blood. So, 1 hour in the film, we had Amy called by the entire audience (this is the truth) a bitch. After getting robbed, Amy turned to her ex: Desi (Harris), which she claimed to have harrased and stalked her. Now I won't tell the rest of the film cause this is where it gets complicated and you would really want to watch it to believe it.
In my overall opinion, this is a flawless film. It had a great script, great score, brilliant acting, superb casting choices and David Fincher. It's basically Fight Club with an over obsessive and bitchy female character. The impressive thing is, it really managed to give each and every characters their own moment to develop and introduce themselves. Heck, even Tyler Perry was great as Nick's lawyer Tanner Bolt (really). David Fincher did an amazing job in executing the book's parallel situations and hardcore sickness (which resembles Amy), partly because he had the writer of the book, Gillian Flynn as the writer of the film. 
However, the most amazing part in the film, would absolutely be Rosamund Pike. Being able to switch and portray a diversive and multi personality character is a hard thing to execute completely (unless you're Edward Norton, who couldn't get his sh*t completely together, as shown in Primal Fear and Fight Club). But Rosamund did a wonderful job in capturing the character's bitchy side and fully develop h? talent to 11. She gave her career best performance, and therefore, would be a fierce contender for an Oscar

Possibly, the most compelling reason to watch 'Gone Girl' in all its seriousness as a murder mystery is how it plays with your mind while being something else too. This isn't a reflection of today's society nor is it a thesis on failed marriages. Based on Gillian Flynn's popular novel and mostly adapted to screen by herself, this contemporary thriller is powered by a dueling narrative that doesn't permit the viewer to take sides for half the movie. Flynn's cinematic adaptation is smart and twisted enough for director David Fincher ('Se7en', 'Fight Club', 'Panic Room', 'Girl with the Dragon tattoo') to delineate his nimble ability with dark thrillers. He then uses his experience of 'The Social Network' and 'House of Cards' to provide a riveting drama that revolves around some powerful characters who face precarious and changing circumstances, neither of which are favorable to them. 

	On the morning of their 5th anniversary, Nick Dunne (Ben Affleck) comes home after sharing his sob story of a struggling marriage with his sister at their bar, only to learn of his wife Amy's (Rosamund Pike) mysterious disappearance. The lead detective's initial suspicions as well as the media's overbearing judgements quickly turn Nick into America's most hated man while he is still coming to term's with her disappearance. This is where the narrative draws excitement with its dual points of view. Nick's deeds and misdeeds provide one angle of what happens in the present while Amy's diary provides insight into their relationship and possibly, motive for her husband to have malcontent.
The element of intrigue generated by these parallel points of view is certainly a result of the synergies between Flynn and Fincher. As guilt, suspicion and negligence become matters of public opinion, media toys with their presentation just as the film's characters, the writer and director tend to manipulate with your interpretation of what really occurs. 
The attitude of media and public might be the American way which seems overblown sometimes but the film doesn't propose absolute seriousness in that aspect anyway. Make no mistake, this is a commercial thriller and therefore, it does offer some cliches and some exaggerations. 

	Hurt by the recession and with their recent move to a small town from NYC, the Dunnes are having more than just financial struggles. Nick's inability to turnaround his career's slide frustrates Amy whereas the constant nagging by her draws him further away from their relationship. With his wife's disappearance, Nick's life not only takes a shocking turn but the constant limelight by the media and public makes it tremendously challenging for him to move on. However, Ben Affleck's brilliant performance doesn't let you determine Nick's sincerity in the scenario. Underneath all the charm and innocence, is there truly a motivated killer or is there another side to the story? 
Amy's sincere narrative quickly draws the viewer's empathy and Rosamund Pike's sincere portrayal of this smart and beautiful writer is delightful to watch. She undergoes transitions both emotionally and physically through the storyline which is yet another portrayal of her commitment to the character. 
The supporting cast has some notable performances which include that of Neil Patrick Harris as Amy's creepy first boyfriend, Carrie Coon as Nick's extremely supportive twin and Kim Dickens as the lead detective whose systematic approach to the case requires her to be stern yet thoughtful as the mystery unravels. 
But with a commanding portrayal of the central character, Rosamund Pike leaves the lasting impression of surprise and delight about such underrated talent. 

	Apart from being a psychologically manipulative thriller, 'Gone Girl' is actually quite an entertainer. There are amusing moments that play in satirical fashion especially when the media and public are overly concerned about missing Amy and how soon they begin to judge Nick's involvement in the disappearance. Then there's Pike's performance that showcases Amy's quick-wit that gently leads to dark humor. While the film maybe a tad bit long, it doesn't lose its grip over your intrigue and that must be attributed to the adroitly written novel and screenplay by Gillian Flynn. 'Gone Girl' may not be an Academy Award contender nor will it make superhero kind of money at the box-office but after a long time, it will be the movie that thoroughly entertained with its darkness, wit and sincere performances.

Having read the book, my opinion of the movie is perhaps tainted and somewhat unreliable. Many book to movie transitions do not work particularly well, and I actually believe that to some extent, this could be one of them. The novel was a fantastic read, and one that I managed to finish soon after starting it. Its layout and tension made it unique and exciting, but at the same ensured that nothing would be a surprise when I came to watch the film. If I were to reverse the order in which I read/ watched 'Gone Girl', my review may have been different.

The two sided diary arrangement to the movie was portrayed relatively well, although seemed to miss chunks of the book, despite being considerably lengthy. Each of Amy's clues and games could have been developed better, as it didn't come across quite as clever and twisted as it did in the book. We also have little exposure to two of the storyline's key characters - Boney and Gilpin. They should have been much more instrumental in the overall plot, undermining almost everything Nick said, whilst becoming genuinely troubled by the case that they were responsible for.

The dramatic twist was still managed to shock me. Artistic shots make this revelation attractive, as we delve into the second half of this arguably very two-sided arrangement. The film improves once this occurs, as the true state of Nick and Amy's relationship is fully revealed.

The ending is suitably creepy and mysterious, just as the book left it. I thoroughly enjoyed the ending, and appreciated the author's decision not to bow down to the pressure for a climatic ending. 'Gone Girl' remains an enjoyable and well directed watch, and I foresee people enjoying it more, should they not have read the book.

Gone Girl, a novel that has been adapted to film and is considered a well made date night thriller movie, is in theaters now.  The literature was published in June 2012 and was written and adapted by Gillian Flynn for the film, which was directed admirably by David Fincher.  The mystery and suspense in the book comes from the main protagonist, Nick Dunne and his involvement or not in the disappearance and possible murder of his wife, Amy Dunne.  Both main characters are out-of-work writers, which Flynn identified with due to her experience of being laid off from her job as a writer for one of the more popular entertainment magazines.
The novel tells a story of the marriage between Nick and Amy Dunne and the reasons for the difficulties they have experienced and why it appears to be falling apart.  The beginning of the book is told alternately by both Nick and Amy and in first person.  Amy's version deals with the past in her journal entries, while Nick's is told in the present. Their stories are different with Amy's account making her appear happier and easier to live with and shows Nick as more aggressive than he says he is.  Nick's version, however, talks about her as being stubborn and unfriendly, while he is not. After Nick loses his job, they move from New York City to his hometown of North Carthage, Missouri where they can help to care for his sick and dying mother.  Opening a bar with the last of his wife's trust fund, running it with his twin sister Margo, it offers a decent living for the three of them, but Nick and Amy's marriage falls apart more quickly.  Amy, unfortunately, hates living in Missouri preferring to have the life she lived in New York City.
Nick becomes the prime suspect in her disappearance.  He used her money, increased her life insurance policy, and comes across as very unemotional in the news; plus, boxes are found of pornography in his woodshed that helps the police to suspect him even further. In the next section of the novel, we find out more about each of them.  Nick has been having an affair and Amy, presumed dead, is alive and in hiding, while she is trying to frame Nick for her demise.  Her diary found by the police is a fake and written exclusively to implicate Nick to them.  The reader learns that Amy is robbed by guests in the motel that she is hiding in and she is left without any money.  She elicits help from a previous boyfriend, Desi, who hides her, but entraps her in his house as he becomes more possessive.  Unable to deal with him and his behavior, she murders Desi and returns home to her husband, telling the public and police that she had been kidnapped by Desi.  Nick believes and is certain that Amy is a killer, but he remains in the marriage because she announces that she is pregnant with his child.  The ending of the novel shows the reader Amy writing that she is about to give birth to her son, and has written a book about her abduction and imprisonment.  Nick had also begun to write his book exposing Amy's lies, but decided against it when Amy revealed that she was pregnant and he wanted a child.
Recognizable in the literature which was carried over into the film are the themes of dishonesty, media misrepresentation, appearances, and the economy's effects on marriage.
The film stars Ben Affleck as Nick Dunne, Rosemont Pike as Amy Dunne, with Neil Patrick Harris as Desi Collings, Tyler Perry as Tanner Bolt (Nick's attorney), and Carrie Coon as Margo Dunne, Nick's twin sister.  Kim Dickens, Patrick Fugit, Casey Wilson, Missy Pyle, Seal Ward, Emily Ratajkowski, Kathleen Perkins, Lisa Banes, and David Clennon round out the admirable supporting cast. 
The film is a close adaptation of the literature where most if not all the story elements have been kept in the movie, which opens on the couple's fifth wedding anniversary, where Nick comes home finding that his wife is missing.  Suspicions arise that Nick has murdered her and his behavior in the media is misinterpreted.  We learn that their marriage has fallen apart with both of them losing their jobs due to the recession and have had to move from New York City to Missouri to look after Nick's dying mother.  Desponded, Nick has become lazy, distant, and unfaithful.  The lead detective, Rhonda Boney, uncovers evidence that point to financial troubles, domestic arguments, and a report where Amy wanted to buy a gun.  We learn as with the book that Amy has faked her death, framing Nick for his infidelity.  She changes her appearance and hides at a campground where she is robbed of all her money forcing her to contact her wealthy former boyfriend Desi to come save her.  She convinces Desi that she fears for her life from Nick and he decides to hide her in his lake house, in essence, trapping her there for his own needs.
Nick hires Tanner Bolt to help improve his public image.  Andie, Nick's student and mistress, reveals their affair at a press conference. Then Nick appears on a talk show and apologizes for his failures as husband, but he is not a murderer.  This appearance improves his image and somehow rekindles Amy's feelings for him.  She seduces Desi, slices his throat and returns home covered in blood, claiming that Desi kidnapped and raped her, clearing Nick of any and all suspicion in her disappearance.  It is here that she tells him the truth and that she wants him back.  Nick tells the detective, the attorney and his sister, but he has no way to prove Amy's guilt. Planning to leave her and exposing her crimes, she tells him that she is pregnant.  He becomes violent, but feels responsible for the child.  He decides to remain with Amy and they announce to the world via a television interview that they are expecting a child.
I love a film adaptation that stays so true to the literature's themes, storyline, plot, characters and dialog which this movie does and does very well that all the essential narrative and core elements are successful interpreted for the viewing pleasure of the audience it is intended for.  The visual elements incorporated in this film are used to highlight the story and plot and are used wonderfully.  The overall cinematography (the film was primarily shot in Missouri) handled by Jeff Cronenweth, was done well and complimented the theme of the recession in Middle America.  Fincher's use of close-ups were expertly handled emphasizing the emotional drama of the story.  He started the film with the same scene that he ended the movie which tied the entire film together.  The framing, editing (by Kirk Baxter), dialog, music (by Reznor and Ross), and acting were all well done. 
This is a well made movie, and I recommend it not as a date night movie, but as a well constructed mystery/thriller for anyone who enjoys that particular genre.  Kudos to Reese Witherspoon and her production company for bringing this book to the screen.

David Fincher is one of the most talented and stylized directors working today. His movies, no matter the subject matter, elevate whatever source material Fincher is given with technical excellence. Ben Affleck smartly left the direction of Gone Girl to Fincher, who, like the main couple in the story, seems a little too perfect for the part. Gone Girl in the wrong hands would be a cheap whodunit, but in Fincher's, it is a dark, haunting tale that punches viewers in the gut. Especially anyone on the Eagle Forum.

I'd go into Gone Girl cold, so SPOILER ALERT AHEAD if you plan on seeing it. On paper, Nick (Ben Affleck) and Amy (Rosamund Pike) Dunne are a run of the mill happy couple. Until the 5th of July, when Nick returns home to find Amy missing. Nick calls the police, and detectives Boney (Kim Dickens) and Gilpin (Patrick Fugit) immediately start to see some issues with Nick's story. Why does Nick not know if his wife has friends? Why is blood left around the house in weird spots? In addition, Amy's public past leads the press to jump all over the story, leading Nick into being the fall guy. With nowhere else to go, Nick moves in with his sister Margo (Carrie Coon) to try to clean up this mess and figure out what the hell happened to his wife.

Fincher's handprints are all over Gone Girl, even though Gillian Flynn adopted her own novel. The sets all feel like dream sequences. Perfect house. Perfect kitchen. Perfect bedsheets. However, Fincher shoots a look of peek around doorway shots, and coupled with Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross's score, Gone Girl feels off and disquiet. Early on, Fincher establishes that these two are writers, and gives us hints of their inner monologues. Smartly, the voice overs have this artificial quality, as if their words don't quite match the story they are telling; when the real world comes crashing back in, the voices go back to normal. These little touches subtly compound to immerse Gone Girl in unease and unreliability, even before the story kicks in.

Gillian Foley's screenplay of her book contains a strong combination of pointed commentary and zig-zag storytelling. The central mystery of Amy's disappearance gets solved about an hour in, but that hour spends its time using media and well-conceived perception to paint a picture of how events went down and who is to blame for the disappearance. Gone Girl then goes on for another hour and a half, but that time is used by letting the reverberations of the big reveal force the main characters to reshape the story to gain the upper hand and find a way out of the precarious situation they all find themselves in. Using media to change a narrative gives Gone Girl a freshness and relevant take on the thriller.

Ben Affleck had me worried for a second. Acting isn't his best profession in the movies (Writer/Director better suit him), and he has every right to coast on his Oscar and Batman moniker. However, Affleck inhabits the everyman Nick Dunne quite smoothly. With all due respect to the new Caped Crusader, Rosamund Pike is the best masked figure. Pike gives Amy an ephemeral quality in every scene she is in; at any point I had no idea where her head was and what Amy's endgame was going to be. Pike effortlessly transitions between sexpot, forlorn wife, and D-lister which Gone Girl requires her to play. Tyler Perry gets to take off a wig and elevate the material as a high powered lawyer of Nick's. Neil Patrick Harris, Carrie Coon, and Kim Dickens are also very good in supporting roles.

Gone Girl is NOT a date movie. The story is pretty dark and out on the pains of being married. Mental and physical infidelity is everywhere. And nihilism and self-interest permeate through David Fincher's direction. If any of you who went on a first date to see Fincher's Social Network, make sure you pick another Fincher movie to propose at.

I like David Fincher a lot and he's made some brilliant films over his career, including some of my personal favourites (Zodiac) and I was looking forward to seeing Gone Girl for a long time.  Unfortunately, it didn't live up to my expectations. 

This isn't Fincher's best by a long way, but I don't think that's his fault, as he does his job as a filmmaker as well as he normally does. It's the source material that I didn't like.  Now, admittedly, I haven't read the novel this is based on, so perhaps the filmmakers took some creative license and changed a lot of things in terms of the areas of the story I didn't like, so if that's the case, the blame lies with them.  However since I don't know either way, I'm going to have to assume the narrative of the novel wasn't altered too much. 

As you'd expect from a David Fincher film, it looks great, the cast does a good job overall and it holds your attention pretty effortlessly. Unfortunately I only liked half of this film. 

The first half was engrossing!  I was invested in the mystery and the portrayal of media sensationalism around the case was brilliantly done. In fact, that was the thing I liked about the movie the most, how the news media and bias, agenda driven panel shows turn real life cases into personal witch hunts. Yet, when the twist is revealed halfway through, I pretty much lost interest because the focus of the story switched massively to something that didn't excite me.

Personally, I found the whole thing too far fetched and the downward spiral of a second half was very disappointing.  It turns into a bit of a character study of someone who, shall we say, is a few puppets short of a Punch & Judy set.  There's a few cliches and a couple of "Oh come onnnn" moan and groan moments.  This may be entertaining and attractive who live for "head fucks" in films, but I've seen a few too many similar things before and feel a bit ripped off with how the film drew to a close.  For what it's worth though, the first half of the film is excellent.   

Overall, Fincher hasn't hurt his film-making reputation as all of his strengths are there, but the story really let me down in the second half as the attention shifted too far away from the element that was grabbing me.

I wanted to like it more, but I felt a bit empty by the end.

We get caught up in the whole idea of thrill rides when we talk about the soundbites that come from merchandising films, especially in the last decade or so. We're promised a roller coaster, but we get the usual, mundane drive to work that we've seen time and again. In Gone Girl we get the opposite. What starts out as your typical Lifetime movie fodder suddenly slams on the brakes and becomes something original in that it takes our emotions on the thrill ride that we're always promised, but rarely receive.

Nick Dunne (Ben Affleck) leads a mundane life with his wife Amy (Rosamund Pike) in South Eastern Missouri. After a pedestrian encounter with his twin sister (Carrie Coon) discussing the chore that going thru the game that has become their anniversary has become, Nick returns home to find his wife missing and the signs of something being afoot. Cue the impending investigation, the secrets that Nick and his wife hold close to their chest, and the transformation from helpless victim to heinous villain and back again. 

Gone Girl is a difficult movie to discuss with someone who hasn't seen the film because you lose the central pivot of the film that everything is centered on. Just as with his previous work, David Fincher has chosen to take us on a ride where we think we know where the hell we're going, but the bus took a right instead of a left and takes us to a shocking new direction that delights us because we just don't know what's going to happen next. That's what makes a movie great- it takes us somewhere we've never been before.

Another aspect of Gone Girl is the way it manipulates the audience and the commentary that this makes with society today, in particular reality television. I can't really call it a commentary. It's more like a metaphysical conversation with the way people turn on a dime emotionally on the screen and the way our emotions as an audience are twisted. You will wonder how gullible these people are, being told how to feel by the talking heads on the television, all the while you're making your decisions on how you feel about the characters based on what you see on the screen. Your feelings for these characters will change more than once as the movie progresses and it's great. It's wonderful to have a film that doesn't have characters that fit right into their cookie cutter positions. It's even better when they can't figure out which little slot they belong in, either.

David Fincher has delivered another masterpiece that can be considered a thrill ride. The audience is emotionally whipped around on his Gone Girl roller coaster, the main difference being that you don't see the curves coming or the big drops that cause our hearts to race and adrenaline to flow. They're just dropped on you. It's like a sunny day after a week of rain. You've almost forgotten what a great film looks like.

Doesn't have the heft of Zodiac or the verve of Se7en but Gone Girl is a masterful adaptation and a superior crime-thriller. It's undeniably entertaining to see a craftsman such as Fincher explore Flynn's thesis by way of rollicking popcorn cinema. Superbly cast from the two at the top to the smallest speaking parts, impeccably directed by Fincher and crafted by his regular team to within an inch of its life, Gone Girl shows the remarkable things that can happen when filmmaker and material are this well matched. Dark, intelligent, and stylish to a fault, Gone Girl plays to director David Fincher's sick strengths while bringing the best out of stars Ben Affleck and Rosamund Pike. Gone Girl is not Fincher's best film, nor is it the most conventionally satisfying of them, but it feels like this is a movie that represents the very best that Hollywood craft can offer at the moment. The editing, with so many twists and turns and so many supporting characters needing their due, is without hiccups. And thankfully, there's plenty of dark humor. A sharply made, perfectly cast and unfailingly absorbing melodrama. But, like the director's adaptation of another publishing phenomenon, The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, three years ago, it leaves you with a quietly lingering feeling of: "Is that all there is?"

David Fincher's Gone Girl is a brilliant piece of filmmaking that boasts a stunning story with an exceptional performance by Ben Affleck. What is great is that Affleck in the last few years is really delivering some solid performances, but in Gone Girl, he delivers his finest performance yet. Gone Girl is a vivid, thrilling drama that is both poignant and riveting from start to finish. The film's plot steadily unfolds in a way that you are slowly sucked into the web of tension that Fincher brilliantly unfolds. I love his work, and I would say that this is his finest film since Zodiac. Here he directs a film that is unlike any other film in his filmography. This picture grabs your attention, and doesn't let go until the final visceral frame. With a steady vibe of tension that really keeps you engaged into the film. Brilliant acted and directed, Gone Girl is one is one of the year's finest pictures, and with that being said, I would go to say that Gone is among my favorites this year, and that's saying a lot considering there has been so many great films, but Gone Girl is a film that really struck a nerve to the point where you're speechless at what you're seeing in front of you. Fincher directs this film as if he is directing a riot, what I mean by that is, is that the film feels like controlled chaos and in that regard, the film is a prime example of an unflinching masterwork that just stays with you long after the credits roll. David Fincher has made great films during his career, but Gone Girl is most likely going to be seen as one of his finest. Brilliantly acted, directed and constructed in terms of sheer mystery and thrills, this is one of the most engaging thrillers of the year, if not the genre.

GONE GIRL BE GONE
What's more ludicrous than Gone Girl? Its selection as the opening film for the prestigious New York Film Festival and the attendant Oscar buzz surrounding this high-gloss trash, that's what. Were it not for its unrelenting smugness, Gone Girl could have been a contender for the camp Hall-of-Fame, but director David Fincher's treatment of this senseless screenplay is so self-important even its social commentary looms obvious and humorless. Ben Affleck, who employs his blank, what-the-hell-am-I-doing-here look in just about any role, doesn't have too far to reach to play a doofus husband wrongly accused of his wife's murder. Rosamund Pike's performance as his psychopathic wife runs the emotional gamut of A to B and back again (to paraphrase Dorothy Parker), and that includes her vaginal insertion of a wine bottle. After a preposterous and plodding 2 hours and 29 minutes, we learn that this doofus and this psychopath will try to make their marriage work. Seldom has cynicism been rendered as stupidly in the movies.

Gone Girl is a beautifully filmed movie.  The atmosphere of most scenes seem to line up perfectly with David Fincher's style.  Frankly, if you've seen other Fincher movies you know what to expect here in both atmosphere and tone.  Ben Affleck was allowed to basically play another version of Ben Affleck, so his lack of acting talent didn't detract from the story most of the time.  Rosamund Pike is beautiful and perfectly executes her role.  Easily, the biggest surprises were Neil Patrick Harris and Tyler Perry.  NPH only reminded me of Barney (from How I Met Your Mother) for a few moments, otherwise he had this really unsettling aura that caused him to steal every scene he appeared in.  And who would have thought there would be a film where I actually liked Tyler Perry?  He was charming, witty, and I couldn't get enough of his character.  So I loved the cast, I loved the cinematography, what caused my rating to be so mediocre?  Well, that's all story-related, and I can't talk about that without hitting on some major spoilers...

I didn't know the entire plot going into this film, so I was surprised a couple times, but I had heard someone describe Rosamund Pike's character as "evil" and that one word was enough to kind of ruin the ride for me.  Not for one moment was I convinced that Nick was guilty, because I knew she was doing something nasty to him.  Instead I just labored through the story waiting for the truth to be revealed.  Luckily that was about halfway through the film, so it wasn't like someone spoiling the Sixth Sense, there was still some movie left to enjoy.  And the story did continue to take more jarring twists, and it kept me guessing.  What I struggled with was the story structure.  It felt like there were so many details (to the point of being overkill) that they included to point the finger at Nick.  It's as if the writer and director had a checklist, as long as Amy had in the movie, of all these points they had to establish.  So we had to keep bouncing from one scene to the next, just piling on all these little details that make him look more and more guilty.  It made the film seem excessively long and I kept wanting to look at the clock to see how much longer it would go on.

Then there was the strange editing of the film.  There were a couple of moments that appeared to be spliced together in the wrong order.  The most blatant was the scene where Tanner Bolt advises Nick that he needs to tell the police about his affair and the items in the shed.  Yet many scenes pass and then later the police find out about these things on their own.  If the editor had just put the reveal scenes of these facts closer to the moment when Nick was given the advice it would feel like Nick was just too late, instead it feels like they ignored Bolt's advice.  But, by far, the biggest issue I have with this film is the ending.  I cannot fathom the final state of affairs as they are presented to us.  They never for a moment establish Nick as someone who would enjoy this artificial relationship.  They go out of the way to make us first question him, but then totally sympathize with him.  Then in the closing scenes he becomes this strange mutant that is incomprehensibly unsympathetic.  What we are left with are 2 primary characters that defy all human logic and feel like they were grown in some type of alien pod.

Despite all this negative stuff I've spelled out, I can't help giving Gone Girl some credit.  For at least an hour afterwards my wife and I were discussing the details of the story.  Any film that has a plot with that much intrigue, which keeps my mind engaged long after I walk out of the theater at least has something positive going for it.  I might not have enjoyed all the details, but there was enough in there that I was compelled to write one of my longest reviews ever.

Over the last two decades, David Fincher has directed what I consider to be three modern classics - 'Fight Club', 'The Curious Case of Benjamin Button' and 'The Social Network'. Yet, unless he changes direction significantly, he will probably be remembered for the dark, sleek thrillers that he seems to be able to produce at will. And what a filmography he has amassed in the genre - 'The Game', 'Se7en', 'Panic Room', 'Zodiac', and 'The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo' all rank among the best suspense films to come out of mainstream Hollywood in recent years.

Now we have another excellent addition to that catalog. The wicked 'Gone Girl' is a delicious missing-persons mystery based on the best-seller by Gillian Flynn of the same name. I haven't read the much-praised source novel, but I imagine that having Flynn adapt her own work for the screen has led to a faithful adaptation. Her screenplay does an excellent job of running a gauntlet of twists while still maintaining plausibility. Under Fincher's masterful eye, it is transformed into an atmospheric and enticing ride.

The acting must also be praised. Ben Affleck, now uniformly respected as a director, seems to be on a mission here to regain his acting cred. I suspect this was a shrewd bit of casting - the woodenness that Affleck has so often been blasted for works as a blessing here, in a role defined by its striking ambiguity - a man who may or may not be involved with his wife's disappearance. The film constantly asks us to guess the truth that lies underneath that smooth face. When called upon to disrupt that brooding smoothness, Affleck more than delivers, showing flashes of intensity that should go some way towards allaying fears about his ability to play his, ahem, next major film role. The supporting cast is also excellent, with Carrie Coon in particular doing a tremendous job as Ben Affleck's twin sister. But of course, 'Gone Girl' wouldn't work without the Girl, and Rosemund Pike is a revelation as the woman at the center of it all. Ever since she became a Bond girl, she has been stuck with a succession of eye-candy gigs, and I'd never have pegged her for a role like this one. Hopefully, Gone Girl will Go places now.

First, the story. In short, expect the unexpected. Fincher provides a style of thriller that you will not find anywhere else. Quite frankly, I wish to see more films like this: twisted and fun. The ending will leave many viewers unsatisfied, but I see it as a the best of both worlds, leaving some holes for the audience to fill.

Next the acting performances. Ben Affleck plays an excellent spurned husband, but Rosamund Pike is the shining star in what is a mostly dark and gloomy film. Her voiceover and her transformations drive the change throughout the plot, and anything less would ruin the success of the film. It is a bravura performance that should be remembered. The supporting performances from a varied group - including a delightful Tyler Perry - are also very strong, and complete a very well rounded cast. 

Last, but certainly not least, is the soundtrack. Ever since The Social Network, I have followed the musical pairing of Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross, and they do an equally wonderful job on Gone Girl. Ethereal but striking when necessary, it pairs the action wonderfully. Unlike the marriage depicted onscreen, the film is made up of many great pairings: Fincher and Flynn, music and story, style and substance.

I've just seen "Gone Girl". It's perhaps the best movie I've seen this year.

Fifteen minutes into the movie I thought it was going to be just another crime thriller with some clever twists and surprises, but which would never get us deep into the minds of the characters. I was wrong. The movie started becoming more and more, taking us into the minds of the main characters, and taking into its scope subjects like domestic violence, marriage, class, the city/rural divide, mass media, and law enforcement. 

But while the movie takes us into the minds of the characters, it's hard for us to sympathise with them. They are not rounded, multi-faceted, realistic human beings. They have rather bizarre thoughts and are motivated by bizarre desires that we cannot really make sense of. (The girl seems to be motivated by some vague desire to control and punish, while the guy was so naive and yielding it's hard to understand why.) This must take away from the movie's value somewhat.

But I don't think the movie aims to be realistic. The movie doesn't try to observe or illuminate as much as to satirise. First it satirises types of people - like rich white American parents using their kids as their own publicity platform. But it also pokes at some social norms - e.g. the practice of having relatives of crime victims make emotional speeches at police press conferences, society's weak spot with pregnant women and rape victims, the bizarre enormous influence of TV show hosts, the role of lawyers as personal lobbyists and spin doctors. It does all this without dropping its dark, serious tone.

Overall, an excellent movie (8/10). I do recommend it.

Smartly playing filmgoers like a tightly strung violin up until an ending that knocks the wind out of you, Gone Girl provides audiences with a scrupulously plotted puzzler that's as thrilling as it ultimately is depressing. Oh, we're chess pieces...pieces in a intricate game planned from the outset by two master players. Director David Fincher knows how to frame a thrilling Who-Done-It, building suspense in slow burn reveals through steady tracking shots and tight editing. Here, however, he relies strictly on these substantive devices without the stylistic tics evident in his other dark mysteries, Se7en and The Girl on the Dragon Tattoo. As always, his film boasts some downright amazing photography. Teetering between a romantic shadowy glow and sobering white light, Jeff Cronenweth's cinematography beautifully betrays a contrast between the loving and loathing days of a marriage gone wrong. It comes down to story. In adapting her bestselling novel, Gillian Flynn retains some intriguingly complex characters while maintaining the narrative tension.

In this R-rated mystery, a husband (Affleck) sees the media circus spotlight shift to him when its suspected that he might be a player in his wife's (Pike) disappearance. 

Thankfully, Fincher chose two brilliant actors in Ben Affleck and Rosamund Pike to realize Flynn's flawed, unreliable, and, at times, highly unlikeable characters. Then, there's supporting players Neil Patrick Harris, Casey Wilson, and Tyler Perry. Sure it's stunt casting, but its really GREAT stunt casting that informs the story's dark corners. If only all of these great choices amounted to more reward than remorse. The end of the novel takes a definite stand; the end of the film leaves it up to the audience. It's a smart choice but doesn't make the conclusion any less of a bummer. 

Bottom line: Good Will Stumping

The supporting cast is great too, and even Ben Affleck turns in a solid performance (I only noticed his Affleckery a few times), though I think casting him in this part was a bit of a misstep, he's just too likeable for this character. Anyway, it's how the mystery unfolds that is what makes this movie so good. The story is told so precisely, revealing just enough new information at regular intervals to keep you completely engrossed from start to finish. And what a finish it is, it's completely unexpected and leaves you feeling... well I won't say. No spoilers! Suffice it to say that all I could do when the credits rolled was keep repeating "That is fucked up." Both Rhonda Boney (Kim Dickens) of  ("Hollow Man," "Mercury Rising") and Jim Gilpin (Patrick Fugit) ("Almost Famous," "We Bought a Zoo") are assigned to the case of  Dunne and the missing wife.

Perry, better known as the Madea persona from a slew of his feel-good family flicks has a whole new identity as attorney Tanner Bolt.  Like his forgettable turn as the title character in "Alex Cross," Perry exudes the hard-nosed lawyer through and through.
Neil Patrick Harris has a significant supporting role as Desi 
Collings, an old on-again off-again squeeze of Amy's. He has an elaborate plan for keeping her safe.
This one has an interesting twist a la an old school femme fatale element thrown into the stew.

I want to buy David Fincher a drink.  So this is about a woman who completely disappears off the map (Rosamund Pike).  Her husband of five years (Ben Affleck) seems to be genuinely confused and concerned, but in this day and age of 24-hour news coverage, you know that every secret and speck of dirt is going to be scrutinized and presented to the public.  This is based on a very popular book that I still have to pick up; it's been universally praised, and if it reads anything like this twisty screenplay, I can totally see why.  Now I do NOT want to be the one that spoils anything about this; so much of the enjoyment comes from you building your own case as the clues are presented to you, so I will steer clear of specifics.  You do your own detective work to solve this mystery, and this is the type of material that director David Fincher is a master at handling.  It is in the same vein of the Girl with the Dragon Tattoo and Zodiac, but I would say he outdoes those movies, and I would even go so far to say that this is his fourth best film overall.  That's how good of a filmmaker he is; his fourth best movie is a shoo-in to be in my top five for the year, if not top three.  He's just so good at crafting movies, and if you're the kind of person that seeks out critically-acclaimed Oscar films, you don't need to wait for the nominations to be released, you can just go ahead and buy your ticket.  Even the simple camera shots are stellar and you can tell that a lot of care went into every single piece of this film.  The editing does a great job at balancing the present media circus with the past diary entries, and you quickly find out that there is a lot more going on here than meets the eye; the more facts and details get presented, the more difficult it gets to remain objective, and when you get to the reveal, it is as effective as can be.  It's almost like this is two movies for the price of one; when I watched this and got to that aforementioned reveal, my fiancé glanced at her phone, leaned over and whispered to me, "There's still an hour left."  It really could have ended right there and it would have been completely satisfying.  However, there's much more story to tell, and being that I was so into it, I'm glad it continued on because I wanted to see more.  While I personally appreciate the following, you may want to be aware of this going in: it gets overwhelming.  The situation itself keeps snowballing, getting worse and worse, and it's a similar sensation to watching Gabriel Byrne in Miller's Crossing; the deck is stacked against this guy so much, you have no idea how it's going to be possible for him to keep his head above water.  That said, it's not all like that, and you do get well placed moments of humor to give you relief from all the tension.  The score by Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross is very effective (I don't think they outdo the Social Network, though).  It's so tight that you don't feel the length... well, for the most part; I started to feel it when it started entering the final epilogue chapter, but that may be because my bladder was about to burst, as I didn't want to miss a moment of this.  This is dark, brooding, and skillfully crafted, features biting commentary on today's obsessive media coverage and succeeds at every turn.

Gone Girl is the latest film from David Fincher who's made such movies as Se7en and Fight Club. It's been one of the most anticipated films of the year and has been quite a success already. The popularity of the book it's based on is the primary reason for all the anticipation.

Ben Affleck plays Nick Dunne, a man who lets you know right at the beginning of the film that he's not happy about his relationship with his wife at all. But one day he comes home to find out she's gone missing. Detectives hop on the scene to find out if she's just missing or in fact dead. And it doesn't take very long for them to start wondering if Nick actually killed his wife himself. The problems with their marriage and the high amount of money the wife is worth give Nick enough of a motive to be considered a primary suspect.

I recalled hearing the story has a big twist, which I assumed to be at the end of the film. The main twist, or at least the answer to what happened to the wife, is actually revealed about halfway through. So once that is shown, you wonder what else the film has left to offer or surprise you with. Well I can't say I was very satisfied with the note it does end on. The movie is well-made and all the actors are terrific in it though. It's an intriguing premise and Ben Affleck certainly carries most of the scenes as he struggles with not only what's happened with his wife but also all the media attention and scrutiny aimed at him due to it becoming a high-profile national case. Supporting roles by Neil Patrick Harris as a former lover of the wife and Tyler Perry as Nick's Johnny Cochran-like lawyer are especially good. The same goes for Rosamund Pike as the wife herself.

But ultimately once all is done and explained, the details are a bit implausible and it's hard to imagine everything really being pulled off that occurs in the film. Basically, it's a suspenseful film throughout but leaves you feeling kind of empty inside. It could be a case of not living up to the hype, but this is more about not having a satisfying conclusion to an otherwise solid film. Once you've been taken for the ride, you may wonder if it was worth it all. The overwhelmingly positive reviews suggest yes, but there were also people who booed at the end in the theatre I saw it in. I'm kind of in the middle. The whole was not greater than the sum of its parts.

Hollywood's thriller maestro David Fincher became a phenomenon in the late 90's with such genre-redefining works as "Se7en," "The Game" and "Fight Club". Then he seemed to falter a bit by abandoning the unique, edgy psychology of his breakthrough works for a more traditionally stylish and obviously commercial tone.

"Gone Girl" has been hailed as his return to form. The author-adapted screenplay based on Gillian Flynn's novel of the same name resembles Fincher's most beloved movies, equaling the upgraded ambition of the directing. This is hugely entertaining, modern noir storytelling, as well as commendably brainy.

Several critics seem to have made the choice of writing both spoiler-free and more in-depth reviews on the film, or at least specifying which kind theirs is. There are often revelations, twists and game changers in good thrillers, and "Gone Girl" might have particularly dramatic ones. Nothing "Fight Club" grade, though. It's true that some of the most central and fascinating themes and conclusions can't be properly commented on without significant spoilers. I'll exercise restraint and try to be as general as possible.

The movie begins on the fifth anniversary of married couple Nick Dunne and Amy Elliott-Dunne (Rosamund Pike and Ben Affleck). The opening notes are of disappointment; we meet Nick who is complaining to his sister about the state of his marriage in a bar they keep together. The anniversary seems to be an uneasy reminder of something no longer alive.

We follow Nick to his house, where he immediately notices the absence of his wife. There are signs of struggle in the living room. Nick calls the police and a search begins. We begin following Nick on his new mission to find Amy. At the same time we see dramatized sequences from Amy's diary that illuminate the history of the couple. Their relationship gets dissected in a way that's at least as thrilling as the way the mysterious disappearance is peeled open.

Amy and Nick are a superficially perfect couple: ridiculously attractive, creative and successful. Nick is down-to-Earth, charming and kind. Amy is classy, witty and ethereal. In the diary scenes they communicate, give each other space. Then the financial crisis takes both of their jobs and makes Nick completely reliant on his wife's family money. They move from hip New York to tend to Nick's mother in Missouri. Somewhere along these times something seemingly unbreakable will shatter. How and with what consequences connects to the disappearance.

The most obvious presence in "Gone Girl" is that of the media. They are present from moment one in the investigation, following Nick's every move, scripting a dramatic, ever changing story for him to inhabit. An easy string of adjectives tells the audience who to love and who to hate any given day. The film gets satirical on several occasions with its sometimes over-the-top plot developments, but especially when it shows the media. It quite sharply demonstrates the cold manner in which the media tries to manufacture oversimplified narratives both generally and particularly when it comes to violence against women. Amy's apparently violent disappearance is handled as a symbol of all such violence but used exploitatively, with superficial urgency but in a tone that's almost pornographic in its details.

Here we get into the other main part of the movie's thematic plane, namely gender. Nick and Amy seem like perfectly modern people with minimum gender bias. Amy is the head of the house and in charge of their common finances. There is no obvious hierarchy between them, no infuriating clichés of indifferent husbands and nagging wives. But Nick comes from a family where the mother was abused. He is haunted by his father's attitudes. Almost unnoticeable hints of indirect aggression are apparent in his ever courteous, even submissive manners. In a moment of weakness he lashes out to his sister about always being pushed around by women. It becomes clear in the diary sequences that the marriage between these two intellectuals was very much gendered. The people in the marriage dealt badly with this, were entrapped by it, but it is something that marriage itself easily forces upon individuals.

"Gone Girl" has been criticized for pushing the misogynist narrative. I can see where the accusation comes from, and I was myself feeling uncomfortable with such an interpretation while watching the story unfold. But I dare argue that this particular interpretation is just the immediate, surface level one, and that the film both invites and deserves a deeper reading of its layers. Absorbing male chauvinism from this one is as lazy as doing the same with Lars Von Trier's "Antichrist," a different but similarly ambivalent work. Fincher's movies do tend to have a male perspective, but I think similar surface level interpretations that have stemmed criticism for his "Fight Club" are being applied again.

Indirectness is in general "Gone Girl's" greatest strength but also its weakness. The unreliability of different points of view has been accomplished with the expense of relatability in the characters. Author/writer Gillian Flynn has talked a lot about how she has wanted to challenge the requirement of likability in her characters, especially the female ones, to create deep, complex players that one is forced to understand if still distain. Cinematic presentation may be just inferior to literary one in this difficult equation, as the characters seem a bit too elusive. Or maybe it's just that usually stories deconstructing a relationship do so through direct character interaction and the indirect, implicit analysis is just something I'm not accustomed to. One at least has to respect the fact that a tale handling misleading appearances, I:s hiding behind me:s and the elusiveness of identity hides its characters just as they themselves do onscreen.

The actors do pretty well, compensating for the detachment I mentioned above. It's become clear in recent years that Ben Affleck- as ridiculously gorgeous as he still is- does better work behind the camera than in front of it. I don't think he's a failure as an actor, but he is a boring, predictable case. I don't ever remember seeing him transcend in any way, even if he has obviously grown over the years. As everyman Nick he does well in presenting isolation and subtle passive-aggressiveness, but he is so clearly inferior to phenomenal Rosamund Pike in their scenes together that it actually breaks the cinematic spell a bit. So it's not so much that Affleck is bad, Pike is just so exceptionally good. Carrie Coon is also perfectly cast as Nick's sister Margot as is Kim Dickens as Detective Rhonda Boney who investigates Amy's case.

As far as the production goes, Fincher keeps you completely hooked through the whole two and a half hour run of the flick. This is addictive viewing every minute, both through the mysterious plot and the scene-by-scene drama. I dare join the choir: the master is back in his game. As a whole, "Gone Girl" might not be a masterpiece, but it's still accomplished, uniquely engaging, compelling and most importantly has a feel of its own, which is the most obvious indication of an exceptional filmmaker behind the wheel.

The overall dark, mysterious mood is what you'd expect of Fincher as he delves into mainstream material, displaying a deft control of the interweaving points of view, and thundering the climax home. The many sequences of crescendo-building tension will leave you realising how much of your breath you've been holding in. The biggest disappointment of the film is that the resolution feels slightly uneventful, leaving you expecting something more hard-hitting as the credits roll. Pike is the star here, and keeps giving new surprises during her descent into chilling psychological territory.

Those who know me will know that I am not one to jump on the bandwagon when it comes to a film or a director. Therefore, I hope this will carry some considerable weight: I predict that, much in the way that critics today refer to works as "Orwellian" or "Hitchcockian," the critics of the future will refer to movies and books as "Fincheresque." That's right-- our lord David Fincher has yet to disappoint (come on, it's not like Alien 3 was his fault) after Gone Girl, one of the best films of both Fincher's career and of 2014. This is not a movie that is shaken off easily. Even if you forget parts of the plot after leaving the theater, the aura it casts will stay with you for some time. Individual shots will stick in your mind for weeks to come. It's quite an experience; one that truly gets in your head.
 
Gone Girl is based off of the novel by Gillian Flynn (who also penned the screenplay), and is directed by God David Fincher.  Fincher is known for past ventures into serial killer stories with films such as Zodiac, Se7en, and The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo, and certainly has a presence in his films. He is a director who truly knows how to get the most out of his actors, all while cramming his stories with suspense. Therefore, he's more than well-matched to this material. Gone Girl is the story of Nick Dunne (Ben Affleck) who comes home one morning to find that his wife Amy (Rosamund Pike) has gone missing. However, as circumstantial evidence mounts against him, both the characters in the film and the audience watching it are forced to wonder whether or not Dunne murdered his wife.
 
The difficult thing about writing a review for a film like this is that it's impossible to break down what makes the film good without spoiling it. And this is a movie that, if spoiled, loses a lot of its edge. So really, all I can say about the plot is that it does exactly what a suspense thriller should do, and does it very well. The movie is not scary, not even particularly intense-- but it has an undeniable sinister quality to it that keeps the audience's adrenaline pumping consistently, even in the most innocuous scenes. However, at the end of the day, the film's big twist takes place about an hour into it, and if you didn't see it coming, well, you're not a particularly observant person. Don't get me wrong, though. The film has far more to offer than just random plot twists.
 
This movie is a tour de force from all perspectives. Fincher is at his best, as always. The way he frames his shots, coupled with his usage of music to add to the tenseness of a scene, is utterly intoxicating. He has very little flourish in his direction (if you're looking for style over substance, I recommend Zack Snyder), but what he does have is an abundance of talent that he uses in very precise ways. Namely, getting a good performance out of Ben Affleck. No, not a good one-- a great one. Affleck has a serious shot at Best Actor this year, and even more shocking is the fact that he might actually deserve it. His disingenuous and smarmy style of acting works here, because the character he's playing isn't supposed to be particularly likable or believable. He completely owns this role. In past performances, Affleck has just been a mediocre actor who happened to be cast in a great movie (which is why he's so often lauded), but here... man oh man, he deserves every bit of acclaim he gets. Meanwhile, Tyler Perry and Neil Patrick Harris deliver powerhouse performances, another surprising development, as their latest efforts include Alex Cross and the How I Met Your Mother series finale, respectively. They're just two more fine examples of how well an actor can do when correctly matched with a character.
 
The film is a mystery/thriller first and foremost, but its best moments stem from its social commentary. Much like 2012's The Hunt, this movie isn't remotely afraid of getting into the ickiness of media politics. As soon as Dunne's story is picked up by the media, everyone in the country, from platinum-blonde FOX News anchors to his own sister, thinks that he's guilty. And after all, why shouldn't they? As the film progresses, it becomes less of a mystery and more of a cautionary tale about the dangers of coming to a group consensus without having all the information. The social commentary in this movie is shrewd and unwavering, but Fincher knows not to cram his film too full of rhetoric (you don't want to bludgeon your audience over their heads with your message... *cough cough* Requiem for a Dream). 

Final Score for Gone Girl: 9/10 stars. Dethroning The Grand Budapest Hotel for my second-favorite film of the year is no easy task, but this movie managed to do it with its engrossing story and darkly comic themes. Audiences will undoubtedly love taking sick pleasure in watching this well-crafted film unfold before them. Everything here works like a Swiss watch-- there's not a boring moment in the whole movie. I've been waiting for Fincher to top himself after his latest efforts, but he's succeeded again and again. After this movie, I don't know what he'll do for an encore, but if the past is any indication, it'll be spectacular.

Gone Girl is a phenomenal psychological suspense thriller reminiscent of a lost Hitchcockian style. Gillian Flynn perfectly adapts her novel to the silver screen with a modern, paranoia-inducing story that David Fincher directs exquisitely. The cinematography and editing help accent the dark tone of the film coupled with the eerie and instantly iconic score.

The greatest part of the film, which is difficult to achieve with its unbelievable script, is the acting by Rosamund Pike. With her best performance to date she brings us Amy Dunne, an empathetic, intelligent and borderline sociopathic character that makes you both sob for her yet cringe at her actions. Such a wonderfully dynamic character.

There was nothing much that I could complain about this film although I find that a general audience of this century may find the narrative to drag a bit as little to no action happens through the second act of the film. However, that does not detract from the fact that Gone Girl is a brilliantly made film that deserves acknowledgement and should be a strong contender during Awards Season.
